description.narrative: Comprehensive capacity development program initiated.

comment.narrative: Newly elected parliamentarians entered office in November 2010.

i) MPs capacity for government oversight enhanced, including related to budget, anti-corruption and implementation of national development plan and MDGs ii) ICT platform set up to improve access to information and increase transparency of National Assembly iii) Support institutionalization of womens caucus and develop a gender strategy to inform corporate plan iv) support secretariat to prepare and restructure for next convocation.

i) MPs capacity for government oversight and budget oversight has been improved ii) ICT platform to improve access to information has been installed iii) Women's caucus has been strengthened through training for women MPs iv) Support to the secretariat provided.

i) National Assembly Corporate Plan 2016 - 2020 road mapped and supported the improvement of NA efficiency and effectiveness ii) Members have skills and in house support to initiate, analyze, debate and mark up new bills iii) Capacity assessment contributed to the development of comprehensive interventions and informed follow up project iv) Revised rules of procedure gives members and committees opportunities, rights and privileges to conduct oversight over the executive on the sectoral development plans, anti corruption and other areas of national importance v) Members of National Assembly have essential knowledge on the budget cycle and keys objectives and interpretation and understanding audit recommendations vi) Improved in house systems provide a lane for popular inputs into high - level policy debate, law making and in the allocation of public funds vii) Public communications of the legislatures improved resulting in greater opportunities for citizens to interact with their representatives viii) New ICT platform improved and institutionalized ix) Improve knowledge and awareness among all members and secretariat staff in gender concepts, equality and discrimination x) Secretariat functions professionally and in an independent manner

i) The National Assemblys Corporate Plan 2016 - 2020 has been developed and is currently pending validation and approval by the Parliament. The Plan was informed by the final evaluation of the previous corporate plan (2010-2015). ii) Induction courses were delivered to members of parliament (MPs) on various topics including the legislative process and functions, bill scrutiny and budget process and analysis. The target groups included members of the parliamentary committees on Industry, Trade and Environment; HIV/AIDS; Foreign Affairs, Defence and Security; Administration and Local Authorities; Legal and Constitutional Affairs; Subsidiary Legislation; the newly elected chairperson, committee clerks and legal service department; and journalists. At least 296 MPs (160 men and 136 women) benefited from these trainings. iii) A baseline study and a capacity needs assessment were undertaken whose results informed the development of a follow-up project LSP II. LSP II is also informed by the findings of the terminal evaluation of the LSP I. iv) and x) Support was provided to the secretariat on issues related to the African Parliamentary Network Against Corruption. In particular, rules and procedures pertaining to parliamentary oversight over the executive on sectoral development plans and anti-corruption issues were subject to review. v) viii) Support was provided to meet these targets. The trainings delivered enhanced the ability of MPs to perform their oversight function. For instance, a recent evaluation report demonstrated that the parliamentary committees have been providing better informed recommendations which have subsequently been accepted by the government. ix) The women caucus Tanzania Women Parliamentarians Group (TWPG) received assistance from the project, including support to get funding. The project activities have contributed to gender mainstreaming in parliamentary debates, including budget processes and increase in the number of gender related q

title.narrative: Strengthening protected areas in southern Tanzania

description.narrative: Strengthening the Protected Area Network in Southern Tanzania: Improving the Effectiveness of National Parks in Addressing Threats to Biodiversity.

title.narrative: Strengthening the protected area network in Southern Tanzania
Mid-term review of the Strengthening the protected area network in southern Tanzania (SPANEST) project
WALKING SAFARI GUIDE TRAINING REPORT NOV 2013 2 2
Strengthening protected areas in southern Tanzania

description.narrative: Increase effectiveness of National Parks in protecting biodiversity and provide for long-term ecological, social and financial sustainability
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

receiver-org.narrative: Government of United Republic of Tanzania

description.narrative: Biodiversity management in NPs,GRs, NRs, wildlife migration corridors and dispersal areas is factored into decision making governing land use management

comment.narrative: Landscape level management remains uncoordinated and biodiversity is lost over time within Protected and buffer areas. Current METT scores as follows: RUNAPA (53), KINAPA (52), MKGR (21), MRNR (40) : average: 42

At least 30 elephants fitted with collars in the Great Ruaha Landscape (GRL) Selected TANAPA staff trained on management and monitoring of resources in GRL Ecological study for the two landscapes conducted Installation of communication system and training of users in Ruaha National Park Demarcation of boundaries around Ruaha and Kitulo NP, Rungwe and Mpanga Kipengere GR with beacons

30 elephants in selected elephant populations were collared and monitored through the installed communication and monitoring system for the Great Ruaha Landscape Selected 50 TANAPA staff were provided with comprehensive training on management and monitoring of resources in GRL Ecological study for the two landscapes has been commissioned and is on going. The communication system has been installed and staff have been trained 100 kilometres of boundary demarcation were cleared and 50 beacons installed in Ruaha and Kitulo NP

Ecological Baseline Study Report validated; at least two areas for publication identified & published in peer review journal Awareness materials and advocacy materials for protected Areas in Southern Tanzania developed, printed and disseminated Success stories for SPANEST documented and published

Ecological Baseline Study Report finalized and validation completed. Area of publication is still under discussion among the wildlife authorities for publication to proceed Awareness materials and advocacy materials for protected Areas in Southern Tanzania developed, preparation for printing and dissemination is ongoing Also the interim report covering year one of an elephant monitoring activity in Great Ruaha Landscape as part of the SPANEST Project was produced in May 2016. Monitoring will continue with mapping of important migration corridors involving World Elephant Centre (WEC) Consultant to document success stories for SPANEST recruited

description.narrative: The biodiversity of Southern Tanzania is better represented and buffered from threat within National Parks GEF 53 mill USD
METT scores are improved in the 4 target PAs especially RUNAPA KNP and MKGR

comment.narrative: Current METT scores as follows RUNAPA 53 KNP 52 MKGR 21 MRNR 40 average 42
RUNAPA and KNP both scoring at least 60 An increase in METT scores in MKGR and MRNR to at least 50 monitoring indicates species diversity either unaffected or increased

Midterm Review results have revealed significant improvement in METT scores for the 4 target PAs as follows RUNAPA 66 KNP 61 MKGR 49 MRNR 52 Implying RUNAPA KNP and MRNR have already surpassed their respective projected endoftheproject minimum METT scores whereas MKGR has missed out its predetermined endofproject METT score by 1

description.narrative: No net loss of natural habitat in major habitat blocks identified as critical for wildlife dispersal Two large habitat blocks Greater Ruaha Landscape and GreaterKituloKipengere Landscape are secured with functioning corridors

comment.narrative: Within the GRL TANAPA have management plans for RUNAPA WCS and local government supporting development of Mbomipa and Umemaruwa WMAs In GKKL KINAPA MKGR and MRNR have management plans

A working model for integrating management of NPs and wider productive landscapes is operationalised secures wildlife corridors and dispersal areas covering over 39000 km2 in the GRL and GKKL ecological landscapes

The project collaborated with KNP and Busokelo District Council to introduce a technology on energyefficient stoves in 10 villages within the council which also border KNP in order to reduce pressure on KNP from the villages for fuelwood The 3 PAs were also supported to undertake fair and open processes towards clearing and demarcating their boundaries hence improving relations with their respective neighbouring communities
Furthermore the project collaborated with KNP and Busokelo District Council to train 46 local artisans from 10 villages in the council which also border KNP on installation of energyefficient stoves This technology is cheap and it is expected that the villages will adopt it easily hence reducing pressure from the villages on fuelwood from KNP
The Ruaha Roundtable Forum which brings together researchers from within the project area has continues meeting regularly to share findings challenges and future plans of the respective researches Information and experiences shared in this forum are enhancing ecological monitoring and addressing threats to biodiversity within and beyond the project area

description.narrative: Two national parks RUNAPA and KNPand one game reserve MKGR have increased operational capacity to manage themselves sustainably

comment.narrative: RUNAPA and KNP lack operational capacity to manage park operations and poaching is common MKGR is in a vulnerable state of management and all three PAs open to risks of fire and poaching

Core NP operations strengthened in Southern Tanzania covering over 22000 km2 leading to the effective detection and deterrence of poaching and fire risks and improved relationships with adjacent communities

The project continued implementing planned activities that focus on achieving integrated management of PAs and the wider landscapes Operationalization of some of the planned working groups has given strong indication of success
A range of activities were carried out during the reporting period to increase operational capacity of the three core Protected Areas to manage them sustainably
The motor grader donated by UNDP through the project to RUNAPA has so far accomplished 952 km of roadwork in the park hence significantly improving mobility and accessibility inside the park Whereas the three antipoaching vehicles donated in a similar arrangement to RUNAPA 2 and KNP 1 have maintained good working condition and constantly deployed in the field hence contributing significantly to daytoday protection activities in the PAs The project has also facilitated procurement of walking safaris gears for RUNAPA A stateofthe art digital radio communication system is being installed in RUNAPA and will greatly enhance monitoring of law enforcement and ecology activities when complete
A consultancy to install a radio collaring and monitoring system for thirty 30 Elephants in the GRL is already on progress Operationalization of the monitoring system is expected to give important insights into Elephants daily and seasonal activity patterns hence informing future strategies to conserve them and their habitats
The project has collaborated with TANAPA to set up a GIS Unit at RUNAPA Thanks to TANAPA hq for committing a full time GIS technician to Ruaha to man the centre The unit will enhance RUNAPAs and other PAs capacity to collect store and retrieve data for management use Staff from RUNAPA KNP and MKGR was part of the beneficiaries from the GIS and Remote Sensing training organized by the project These will further facilitate operationalization of the GIS Unit

description.narrative: Integrating management of NPs and broader landscapes in Southern Tanzania
Biodiversity management in NPs GRs NRs wildlife migration corridors and dispersal areas is factored into decisionmaking governing land use management

comment.narrative: Management activities are carried out on WMA district regional government and TANAPA level but with a lack of a landscape level coordination mechanism

Intersectoral District land management coordination mechanism is emplaced in the GRL and GKKL in Southern Tanzania Management actions evidenced as a result of decisions and support of landscape level committees and working groups functioning beneath them land use planning unit ecological monitoring unit tourism unit community conservation unit and enforcement unit

The motor grader for RUNAPA by UNDP through the project and has so far accomplished 952 km of roadwork in the park significantly improving mobility and accessibility inside the park The three antipoaching vehicles donated in a similar arrangement to RUNAPA 2 and KNP 1 have continued being in good working condition and constantly deployed in the field hence contributing significantly to daytoday protection activities in the PAs The project has also facilitated procurement of walking safaris gears for RUNAPA
A consultant was also engaged to install stateofthe art digital radio communication system in RUNAPA Installation progress is beyond 80 Among other things the communication system will be allowing proper linkage of ecological management objectives such as the monitoring movement of radio collared elephants and security management objectives such as monitoring rangers locations and movements from an operational HQ through LCD screen platforms The communication system includes 15Solar powered digital VHF High power base stations at Ranger posts and Park HQ 5 Repeaters Units and Six 6 digital VHF High power vehicle radio units with GPS capability installed and operational in six vehicles
The consultancy to review governance systems and operational practices in the two project landscapes has been completed and the final report shared amongst relevant stakeholders Recommendations from the consultancy have greatly informed the process towards formation of the Landscape Coordination Committees
The project is now finalizing the installation of a digital communication system for Law enforcement in the GRL With digital handheld radios VHF High Power Base Stations and LCD screen monitors the communication system will greatly improve monitoring of law enforcement and ecological activities in the GRL
Installation of the Elephant Collaring and Monitoring system which is already underway in the GRL is expected to greatly inform future strategies to conserve and monitor the flagship species other wildlife species and the general habitat
The project has collaborated with TANAPA to set up a GIS Unit at RUNAPA that will serve southern National Parks and other PAs Moreover a tailormade training on GIS and Remote Sensing was offered to 26 individuals from TANAPA WD and District Councils who will work closely with the expert manning the GIS unit in RUNAPA
The project further supported acquisition of a tollfree mobile number from VodacomTanzania 0800751212 through which good the public can report any poaching informationincidence free of charge The number has been printed on posters and widely disseminated

description.narrative: Bujingijila and Numbe valley corridors gazetted

comment.narrative: Wildlife are not able to move from GRL to GKKL linkages are weak within GKKL PAs
Mpanga Kipengere linked through Numbe valley corridor to Kitulo NP to enable merging the two parks Bujingijila also allows linkages to Mount Rungwe Nature Reserve

Bujingijila corridor has been secured following survey results showing that the whole area thought to be Bujingijila corridor actually falls within both KNP and MRNR The 32 km long shared boundary of the two PAs along that area has been permanently demarcated with 7 drumsize beacons
A preliminary survey on Numbe Valley Corridor was conducted by a team comprising staff from Makete District Council KNP MKGR and SPANEST The preliminary survey outcomes included a proposed course of actions to secure the corridor The proposed course of actions includes awareness meetings to 3 villages adjacent to Numbe valley facilitating land use plans in the villages and carryout a physical survey These are included in the budget for 201516

description.narrative: Development impacts in sensitive areas have been mitigated monitoring and reporting systems are in place and enforcement measures are operational in GRL and GKKL landscapes

comment.narrative: Monitoring of species and habitats is managed on an individual PA level understanding of wildlife corridor functions species movements and dispersal areas limited

A systematic conservation plan for both landscapes that balances biodiversity needs defines wildlife corridors and dispersal areas with EIA and ME systems has been ratified is in use and is informing measures to address threats to biodiversity in core areas and corridors

SPANEST Anti poaching campaigns with local artists resulted in composing of 7 songs the on elephant poaching crisis and local tourism promotion
Official launching of the songs is under way
The project has collaborated with Iringa District Council to organize and facilitate a visit to the northern Tourist circuit in Arusha and Manyara for the representatives from Malinzanga village Maasai women group The purpose of the mission was mainly for the group members to observe and learn on relevant cultural activities that could be implemented by the women groups in Malinzanga and project area
The project has received proposal from Iringa district to collaborate in the development of a women cultural centre at Malinzanga on the route to Ruaha Np The project intends to set aside some funds to develop the centre in collaboration with the women and the district

description.narrative: Mpanga Kipengere GR is upgraded to NP through consultative process

comment.narrative: Mpanga Kipengere GR is managed on a meagre budget fires and poaching are rife tourism is minimal
Mpanga Kipengere Game Reserve is raised to higher protected area status as a national park
It was determined to not follow up on the Mpanga Kipengere PA status this year This was assessed in the MTR

description.narrative: Public consultations are completed in an open and fair manner beacons mark PA boundaries clearly

comment.narrative: Recent developments in PA status especially in western Kitulo area Mpanga Kipengere and Usangu mean boundaries are not clear conflicts are a result
Agreed boundary beacons are in place around three PAs RUNAPA KNP and MKGR including newly gazetted areas such as Usangu

The project support towards clearance of PAs boundary and installing beacons has been participatory and significant In RUNAPA a boundary stretch of 100 km which is disputefree is being cleared and will be followed by installation of 100 foursided beacons In KNP a boundary conflict with a neighbouring Mpangala village was resolved in an open and fair manner hence enabling proper demarcation of the villagepark shared boundary with 20 drumsize beacons Further 7 beacons have been installed along the shared boundary between KNP and MRNR In MKGR awareness meetings on boundary demarcation have been convened in 10 neighbouring villages in collaboration with respective 3 district authorities including the District Commissioners The meetings paved way to clearance of a 60 km boundary stretch
The Project Unit is already working with WD and other stakeholders for best way forward on the matter as directed by the 4th Project Steering Committee
RUNAPA collaborated with the Project and Mbarali District Council to undertake Land use Plans in three villages within the district which also border RUNAPA
This was a followup initiative to the training on Land Use Planning and Related Laws for PAs and District Councils staff that was funded by SPANEST and conducted by the National Land Use Planning Commission The exercise aimed to enable the 3 villages to use their landbased resources sustainably hence reducing pressure on the park The exercise was further an opportunity for the land use planningtrained staff from RUNAPA SPANEST and KNP to practise their knowledge and skills
In FY 201516 the project has set funds to implement Land Use Plans in 4 villages within Chamwino district in Dodoma region The villages border GRL hence the expected output will be reduced pressure on the adjacent PAs caused by encroachment and other unsustainable land uses
In GKKL the project and KNP involved the Makete District Defence and Security Committee to resolve a boundary conflict between KNP and Mpangala village The conflict was resolved and the share boundary is already permanently demarcated

description.narrative: Relations with neighbouring communities to PAs considerably improved lower instances of human wildlife conflict fires and poaching

comment.narrative: TANAPA has community conservation service departments in RUNAPA and KINAPA however parkcommunity relations remain strained in some crucial border areas
TANAPA has a staffed community extension services to ensure effective engagement between communities and park authorities and dispute resolution

TANAPA Community relationship continue to be improved through the engagement of the community representatives in common activities such as meetings visits and consultations
Project members participated in a number of official meetings organized by MBOMIPA association
SPANEST Project in collaboration with RUNAPA Pawaga and Idodi Divisions in Iringa district and the Football Association of Iringa district jointly organized football competitions for the youth representing 21 villages bordering Ruaha National Park
The aim of the competitions named SPANEST Cup is to bring together the majority of youth from the villages to be educated on the escalating elephant poaching in the park and how the youth could be involved in tackling the crisis The fact that the majority of the members of the community involved in poaching events are the youth SPANEST thought for a need to ensure
Over 120 matches involving 21 villages over 250 youth players have so far participated in the competitions since the launching of the cup in July 2014 to the current stage of final
Over 150000 young men and women and other community members from Idodi and Pawaga divisions 21 villages participated in the matches and were able to receive a message on the current situation of the elephant poaching in Ruaha and how they could participate to stop it
The number of people who were involved and educated about the elephant poaching crisis during the two months of the campaign was higher than any public gathering event that anyone would organize

description.narrative: Two specialist units are developed by TANAPA with partners a land use planning unit and an ecological monitoring unit

comment.narrative: TANAPA has community conservation service and ecology departments in RUNAPA and KINAPA however lacking adequate coordination functions with external parties
TANAPA has the competence and staff skills to lead land use planning management and monitoring in landscapes

The working groups on the themes of Law Enforcement Tourism Community Conservation and Ecological Monitoring Ruaha Roundtable continued with their respective operations enhancing cooperation and coordination amongst stakeholders in the project area These working groups are diverse with members from TANAPA WD TFS Regional and District authorities WMAs Police and the Private Sector The community Conservation working group for GRL with members from RUNAPA SPANEST WD and District Councils collaborated with District Defence and Security Committees to conduct conservation awareness campaign in 11 villages aiming at enhancing the understanding of communities on matters related to wildlife conservation and associated potential benefits in order to gain their support in the fight against degradation of natural resources and poaching
The operational groups on Law Enforcement Tourism and Community Conservation are already removing barriers between conservation stakeholders in the project landscapes For instance the NjombeIringaMbeya Inter Regional Tourism Committee successful managed to mobilize tourism stakeholders from the southern circuit to participate in Karibu Fair staged annually in Arusha as one team for the first time The team shared a booth hence provided onestop information centre for Tanzania Southern Tourist Circuit The Community Conservation Working group in the GRL which is multisectoral worked successfully with District Defense and Security committees to promote conservation awareness in 11 villages bordering the GRL
Tourism Committees for Njombe Mbeya and Iringa have formed an interregion tourism committee that is now overseeing tourism related activities beyond the respective regions confines This umbrella committee managed to mobilize tourism stakeholders from the southern circuit both public and private to participate in Karibu Fair that is staged annually in Arusha bringing in tourism stakeholders from allover the world The group shared a stand and managed to promote the Southern Circuit collaboratively The committee is already working to stage southern circuits own fair in Iringa in 2015

description.narrative: Operations Support for National Park Management in Southern Tanzania

Finance and business planning has established management costs for different PAs and WMAs and provides accurate revenue forecasts for each PA and the wider landscape GRLGKKL and matches revenue to priority management needs

comment.narrative: Business planning in southern Tanzanias PAs lacks local context and full understanding of the international dimension of financial and business planning requirements business planning is limited a s result

A sustainable finance plan is developed approved and implemented for the PA system in both GRL and GKKL landscapes Business Planning is mandated for four PAs as well as for two adjacent WMAs along approved best practice guidelines

TARGET EURO Consult was awarded a consultant by UNDP to develop tourism development and Marketing strategy The consultant has completed the assignment and the strategy is in place and a final draft was shared and presented before key Tourism stakeholders from the Landscapes The strategy will be used to inform Finance and Business Plans which will be developed in the financial year 20152016
The project along with other stakeholders supported development of a video documentary for promoting tourist attractions in Makete District and Njombe region
Another 30minutes documentary featuring project activities since the start of the project was developed and features on Air through a local TV Star TV

description.narrative: Ranger and staff training programme in existence in RUNAPA and KNP MKGR has joint TANAPAWD programme guide training and documentary programmes in existence

comment.narrative: Rangers have insufficient capacity in RUNAPA KNP and MKGR to gather intelligence on poaching and fires relations with tour operators and tourists often strained because of lack of customer care capacity lack of valueadd services

Systematic staff training programme covering all aspects of PA operations ensures 300 rangers guides and other field staff meet appropriate competencies according to skill set eg enforcement community relations tourism etc

The project continued to facilitate trainings for PAs staff and other stakeholders geared towards bridging preestablished knowledge and skill gaps
TANAPA rangers training to develop a Rapid Response Unit for Ruaha National Park rangers which involved three stage training Selection Basic Paramedics Commanders and Intensive training At the end of the training a team of 37 Rangers successfully completed the training aimed to develop and equip them for rapid response to poaching incidences in the Great Ruaha Landscape The training was conducted by Aegis Defence Services Limited Aegis a UKbased company The Rapid Response Team is already deployed in RUNAPA whereas TANAPA and the project have further strengthened the team by providing them with patrol equipment and f gears
During the reporting period a 56 percent decrease of poaching incidences in Ruaha National Park was reported by TANAPA whereby a total of 36 elephants were killed in the year 20132014 compared to 82 elephants in the year 20122013
During the same period TANAPA reported on the Improved average time of rangers patrol deployment by 30 and 54 for Ruaha NP and Kitulo NP respectively through patrol vehicles donated by SPANEST project
Staff from RUNAPA KNP and MKGR was part of the participants to tailormade trainings on GIS and Remote Sensing and Open Performance Review and Appraisal OPRAS The training on GIS and Remote Sensing was necessary in order to enhance improved collection storage and analysis of field data in the PAs and across the project landscapes The Open Performance Review and Appraisal System OPRAS are generally accepted as the best appraisal system around in terms of motivating employees and ultimately enhancing efficiency and effectiveness at working stations Staff from RUNAPA KNP and MKGR were trained on OPRAS alongside other project stakeholders in order to enhance staff motivation and hence efficiency in the PAs
The Village Game Scouts for MBOMIPA WMA were supported uniforms and other field gears by the project in order to strengthen security in this PA which borders RUNAPA

description.narrative: Stakeholder groups in both RUNAPA and KNP are engaging positively and constructively on biodiversity management

comment.narrative: There is a marked lack of communication largely due to insufficient funding between different PA authorities local government communities civil society and the private sector causing inefficiencies misunderstanding and occasional conflict
A joint TANAPACommunityDistrictPrivate Sector stakeholder group formed to address overall intelligence in support of enforcement action both RUNAPA and KNP

The project further supported conservation education in 8 villages adjacent to GRL in Chamwino 2 and Manyoni 6 districts which was provided collaboratively by the WD Publicity Unit RUNAPA RungwaKizigoMuhesi and relevant officials from the districts The Law Enforcement Working Group for the GRL managed to coordinate 2 joint patrols The fair and open process involving demarcation of PAs boundaries is proving success and is enhancing good relations between the PAs and the adjacent communities This is important especially now that the project is moving towards creating Landscape Coordination Committees which will be charged with overseeing matters related to land and Natural resources in respective landscapes including monitoring the operations of the various work groups In FY 201516 Formation of further two working groups on Land use Planning and Ecological and Water Resources Monitoring will be finalized
MBOMIPA WMA was facilitated by the project to participate in UNDP Equator Initiative were they won a prize award Two representatives from the association were also facilitated to attend the award ceremony in Nairobi Kenya
The project budget for FY 201516 also has provision for formulating a joint working group for GRL and GKKL specific for Ecological and Water resources Monitoring The work group shall be guided by a joint work plan

description.narrative: The input of increased HR capacity and funds for equipment following a business planning approach has lead to greater efficiency and effectiveness of park operations in RUNAPA and KINAPA

comment.narrative: RUNAPA and KNP lack operational capacity to manage park operations in a sustainable manner gaps exist in HR across park operations lack of equipment means difficulty to manage fires poaching and monitoring the ecosystem
Funds human resources and equipment are provided and deployed to address threats to RUNAPA and KINAPA in a cost effective manner utilising business planning in cooperation with police and judiciary

A tailormade course on Open Performance Review and Appraisal Systems OPRAS was facilitated for 17 staff from TANAPA Tanzania Wildlife Division Tanzania Forest Services and District Councils Performance appraisal was one of skills gaps identified within the project area
50 individuals from public and private sectors were trained on customer care as a way of equipping them to participate in effectively in the service and tourism sectors which hold huge potentials in the southern regions of Tanzania

comment.narrative: Deforestation and degradation resulting form settlers, land clearance and burning for agricultural activities, saw millers, tobacco industry, charcoal producers and climate change currently estimated at 10%

At least 500 ha of community forests being managed under JFM and CBFM regime supported Research on the charcoal production and consumption chain conducted Farmer groups facilitated to form primary societies that will facilitate access to microfinance Adoption of charcoal strategy and action plan including lessons for policy advice

At least 500 ha of community forests are now under JFM and CBFM management arrangement Research on the charcoal production was conducted and report was validated by stakeholders. 7 Farmers groups in 4 wards have been formed, trained and they are now ready to access microfinance facilities. a regional workshop was convened and deliberated on the adoption of charcoal strategy and action plan was drafted.

Conduct Project Steering Committee Finalizing the Forest Resource assesment in two districts of Tabora region under the Project Project Midterm Review will be conducted to assess progress towards achievement of the project

Two project boards were conducted as per plan one in February and the other one was done in August. Forest Resource Assessment in two districts completed The Mid-term review was conducted and report was provided with positive observations. Lessons on project design was acknowledged noting comparatively high degree of complexity, ambition, and geographically dispersed activities loaded under the four outcome areas. All these observations were addressed in the management responses and presented to PSC meeting. The lessons will also inform future project design.

description.narrative: (i) MDAs incorporate sectoral policies consistent with national pro-poor strategies (ii) Availability of data for evidence based pro-poor economic planning and budgeting (iii) # of key national institutions developing enidence-based pro-poor economic development policies and strategies

comment.narrative:
Sector policies and plans in place with varying degree of integration of environmental sustainability
Key government staff have inadequate information and knowledge in poverty reduction and employment enhancing growth with environmental sustainability

Support to consultative review of FYDP I and development of draft FYDP 2015/16 2020/21 provided Six poverty, environment and gender pilot projects developed and implemented in selected PEI districts Five local projects on fish farming, horticulture and beekeeping funded through TWIGA Bank 10 consultative dialogues on Post 2015 Development Agenda conducted South-South-Cooperation on sustainable fish farming techniques facilitated for CBOs, District Extension Officers, Academics and representatives from the National Service Corporation (Thailand, Uganda, Kenya, South Africa) 2 District Investment Plans integrating poverty, environment and gender concerns developed

The formulation of the second Five Year Development Plan for mainland Tanzania and the MKUZA Successor Strategy for Zanzibar are informed by studies and evidence on poverty, environment and gender issues. Nature-based pilots on fish farming, beekeeping, agriculture, and forestry management implemented in 6 districts. Biogas systems installed in 10 households benefiting 121 people in Sengerema district. This resulted in reduced time spent by women and children collecting firewood and cooking (from approximately 6 hours to 1 hour per day); leaving time for other productive activities. Over 35 famers groups (60% women) have embarked on beekeeping in 3 project Districts following trainings in modern beekeeping techniques. Memorandum of Understanding signed with Twiga Bancorp on soft loan package. The Bank received 124 applications for nature-based enterprises (54 women and 70 men). Selection and approval process is ongoing. Training of 35 members of Savings and Credit Co-operatives (SACCOS) and Village Community Banks (VICOBAs) from 3 Districts (10 women and 25 men) enabled the participants to prepare business plans and bankable projects evidenced by the quality of bank applications. In addition, the training has enabled a larger number of farmers, who were previously excluded from bank services, to open bank accounts. Planning Commission in collaboration with Ministry of Finance successfully led the post-2015 development agenda discussions, helping Tanzania in the preparation for implementation and monitoring of the SDGs. A total of 131 people from government, civil society, media, research institutions and UN participated in the consultations in 2015 (92 men and 39 women). South-South Cooperation on aquaponics technology facilitated with the aim of introducing the hydroponic fodder technology in Tanzania. Study tour to Kenya for 10 key beneficiaries conducted and 31 farmers (10 women and 21 men) in the Lake Zone trained. Consequently, one farmer embarked on t

- At least 2 technical cross-sectoral coordination meetings held to strengthen sector coordination on poverty, environment and gender issues - No. of Sector policies and plans that integrate poverty and environment linkage objectives - The FYDP II reflect poverty, environment and gender objectives - At least one analysis report on the contribution of environment and natural resource management to poverty reduction, social transformation and gender equality produced - Women benefit from participation in poverty reduction interventions in the 6 Districts

- Cross-sectoral coordination meetings supported through the FYDP II Technical Taskforce - 2 Sector plans integrate poverty and environment linkage objectives, namely, the Fisheries Policy (2015) and the draft revised National Environment Policy - Several sections of the FYDP II focus on environment management and poverty reduction. These include Section 4.2.6 on Natural Resources Management, Environment and Climate Change; section 4.2.7 on Tourism sector development; and section 4.3.4 on protection and conservation of natural ecosystems as sources of water for a wide range of uses including household domestic use, agriculture, hydro-electric power generation etc. Furthermore, the plan includes targets for human development and poverty reduction with a focus on multi-dimension poverty index (MPI) as a means to monitor progress of government programmes and the expected improved macro-economic performance to poverty reduction and human development. Also, the new national development plans include interventions that are likely to have a positive impact on GEWE e.g. enhancing low cost credit to women; increasing health insurance coverage; enhancing employability and entrepreneurship skills of women; supporting sustainable water and land use management; and disseminating local technologies for household cooking in substitution of fuel wood and charcoal - 2 reports produced including Cost benefit analysis of sustainable livelihood enhancement interventions in 6 districts and Gender gap in agricultural productivity study - CBA shows that livelihood interventions on fish farming and beekeeping in 6 districts had a positive impact on womens economic empowerment and ability to provide for the household. Previously, these were male dominated activities that women could not engage in. This has changed. Also, introduction of biogas plants in 1 district has reduced time spent by women and children fetching fuelwood; increasing time spent by women on productive economic act

PEG indicators integrated into PMMP Gender gap study conducted 3 regional investment guides developed CBA printed and disseminated FYDP II implementation plan developed National guidelines for cage fish farming developed SDGs baseline report highlighting progress on pro-poor/p-e objectives indicators

description.narrative: (i) Capacity needs assessment of trade related institutions in Zanzibar (ii) Scooping studies for two key identified products with export potential (iii) Bi-Annual meetings of Trade Integration National Steering Committee (TINSC) (vi) Government and Donors Quarterly Trade Integration Technical Committee (TITC) Meetings (vii) Selected trainings for staff in the National Implementation Unit (NIU) and the trade related MDAs.

comment.narrative: (i) Validated DTIS Action Matrix in November, 2005 (ii) 2012 productive sector MDAs strategic plans (iii) Bi-Annual Trade and Industry Thematic Group (iv) Inactive TINSC meetings (v) Inactive TITC meetings (vi) Few Joint Donor initiatives

i) Building capacity of avocado producers in quality compliance ii) Develop entrepreneurial skills for youth, women and SMEs engaged in honey production iii) Training in 4 zones for regional trade officers on trade promotion and development iv) Support development of Zanzibar international trade and conventional center master plan

i) 75 men and 30 women from the 3 regions with highest avocado production potential, were trained on quality compliance for production of avocado ii) Entrepreneurial skills were provided to 100 youth and women engaged in honey production. Also 16 SMEs participated in international trade fair where they were able to link with potential buyers. Furthermore, the SMEs competitiveness was increased by having their products certified and enabled to acquire barcodes which provides them with a broader market access. iii) Training for regional trade officers on trade promotion and development was conducted in 4 zones namely the southern highlands, central, northern and lake zones. iv) The Zanzibar international trade and conventional center master plan was developed and approved by the Cabinet.

i) Capacities of staff from the Ministry of Industry, Trade and Marketing (MTIM)-Zanzibar enhanced in data management and update of data portal. ii) Draft project proposals for Tier 2 projects have been developed and are currently under review and comments iii)Terminal Evaluation on Capacity Development for Mainstreaming Trade report finalized and submitted. The terminal evaluation report be used to inform future programming

description.narrative: 1. Reform Coordination Mechanism established, 2. Resource mobilisation for the reform initiated.

comment.narrative: Zanzibar legal sector has no holistic reforms since indepence (1964).
Implementation of Legal Sector Reform Strategy supported. Case management system developed and adopted. Legal Aid Policy approved by the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar.
Implementation of Legal Sector Reform Strategy started and is on going. Case management system is being developed but not yet adopted. Legal Aid Policy has not yet been approved.

i) Legal Sector Reform Strategy developed and implemented ii) Enhanced institutional and operational capacity of the justice sector institutions to deliver services efficiently and effectively iii) Legal aid policy, legislative and regulatory frameworks developed and operationalized iv) Project Board Meeting

The legal sector reform strategy was successfully developed and is currently being implemented as the strategy provides broader guidance all legal sector matters. In enhancing institutional and operational capacity of the justice sector institutions to deliver services efficiently and effectively, various trainings have been conducted including; administration of contracts to AGC staff, specialized training on prosecution skills specifically on prosecution of cases related to corruption and drug trafficking. These trainings involved ZAECA and DPP staff. Also adjudication of cases skills training was carried out to judiciary staff in relation to this. The legal aid policy was developed as per plan however; it is not in use yet waiting for endorsement by the government. In addition the case management system and records keeping is currently being updated into an online system which will increase more transparency and reduction of case log. The development and operationalization of legislative and regulatory frameworks are subject to endorsed legal aid policy hence are not developed yet. At least two project board meetings have been conducted this year where in both meetings various strategies for effective project implementation were recommended including approval of work plans.

i) Legal sector Reform Strategy and action plan implemented ii) High court case flow management system developed and adopted iii) Case record system for high court registry developed and adapted iv) Prosecution training to prosecution staff conducted v) Negotiation and alternative dispute resolution training to AGs chambers officials conducted vi) Specialized training to LRC commissioners and researchers conducted vii) Forensic manual through consultative process developed and adopted viii) Legal aid entity developed established and functional ix) Legal aid law developed x) Code of conduct for legal aid providers through a consultative process developed

description.narrative: M&E report for environment and social protection is published. National MDG and annual performance and service delivery reports published. Auditors trained in performance and attached to ISSAI. Baseline study on youth employment programs undertaken.

comment.narrative: Weak poverty M&E system. Weak institutional arrangements. National Audit Office quality of audit services does not match with international standards, and NAO staff lack skills in specialised areas. Youth employment opportunities need to be enhanced.

The Poverty Division M&E database produce timely statistics and the Local Government Monitoring Database is functional Analytical support provided to the review of the FYDP I and to inform the next five year national development plan High quality MKUKUTA Annual Report 2014/15 produced, which informs the development of the next five year development plan Online Tourism portal developed and launched Community radios in five districts (Bunda, Sengerema, Nyasa, Kagera and Ileje) established Mobile agricultural platforms piloted in two districts

The Government is able to better integrate data and evidence in national planning processes evidenced by the MKUKUTA II review and formulation of the second Five Year Development Plan for mainland Tanzania, which are informed by studies and reports on poverty eradication, inequalities and vulnerabilities. The online Tourism Portal was launched: http://www.tanzaniatouristboard.com/. The Portal contains updated and detailed information with the view to attract more tourists to Tanzania and create employment. E-teaching pilots scaled up to 5 schools in Bunda and handed over to the District for further up-scaling through integration into district planning and budgeting. The service has contributed to improve the quality of teaching in the 5 schools as well as student engagement, motivation, and attendance. 5 community radios established and supported to enhance knowledge in the communities and give the villagers a voice to raise their views and concerns. E-agriculture as a public-private-partnership mechanism scaled up to two additional districts using the interactive mobile agriculture platform (M-Kilimo), which enables farmers to access markets and receive information from agriculture extension officers (http://mkilimo.esrf.or.tz/index.php/en).

i) Improved poverty M&E system. Monitoring and Evaluation Plan for Poverty and FYDP II. ii) Government e-portal operationalised. iii) Investment opportunities and facilitate district investment forums and smart-partnerships identified. iv) Platforms for sharing community knowledge and best practices operational. v) 6 districts localised SDGs/FYDP II.

i) UNDP provided Technical Advisory and supported stakeholders consultations in the drafting of the FYDP II that was launched in June 2016. The project supported the preparation of the MKUKUTA Annual Implementation Report which was published in April 2016. The report covered the assessment of MKUKUTA II in areas such as growth and income poverty, and monitoring and evaluation systems. Support was also provided to develop a Local Economic Development (LED) roadmap and tools for designing and implementing the LED agenda. ii) Supported procurement of equipment to support the establishment of cage culture for communities in Karukekere, Bunda district and in Kemondo, Bukoba Rural district. The project supported the creation of employment for 99 young people, out of which 63 are women. Procurement services delivery through UNDP-Government cost sharing agreement has enabled GPSA to ensure that the Government gets value for money. iii) JKT received support to construct and install a modern Fish Hatchery, procurement of 24 polyethylene cages and installation of fish feed plant at Bulamba detachment. The support was also extended to repairing and constructing ponds. Rwamkoma JKT staff also attended trainings at Sokoine University and in Uganda on Fish propagation. iv) 35 TV and Radio Programmes were produced on different developmental sectors and disseminated through community radios. 1,120 relevant documents were entered into Tzonline databases. Tanzania Knowledge Network platform moderated 5 topics covering issues of national interest which stimulated discussions attracting over 5,000 viewers and contributors. The contributions informed the development of policy briefs. Three Community radio stations were finalized and begun to broadcast. These are Ileje, Unyanja and Bunda FM community radios with a total audience of about 4,000,000 people. They are broadcasting educational programmes which include information from this and other projects. v) Localization of SDGs/LED w

description.narrative: Awareness on challenges and opportunities for enhancing aid effectiveness accessible to DPG Main and general public.

comment.narrative: DP commitment to the harmonization and coordination agenda reduced over the past years due to weak, ineffective and scarce results-based dialogue.

Statutory monthly meetings arranged including strategic discussions on the Financing for Development, SDGs and COP21 Initiation of a new dialogue structure/partnership Dedicated support to DPG Working Groups (PMG, HIV, PFM)

All Statutory meetings held in 2015. Strategic dialogue with Government undertaken with Ministry of Finance, Vice President's office invited to present national plans and strategies. Discussions held on the F4D implications for the Government and preparations of the COP21 DPG hosted the first session to brainstorm on a possible new aid architecture (internal to DPs) Continued support to the DPG working group for PFM (UNDP has recruited a dedicated PFM specialist to run the DPs PFM secretariat)

Facilitation of key DPG processes, including statutory meetings and DPG Field Trip 2016 Busan Survey on development cooperation completed Effective support to the co-chairs for the aid architecture review process Communication support and continuously updated Webpage Support to PFM DP working group

Continued support to the DPG Group and DPG field trip organized with a thematic on social protection. During the visit, the group had an opportunity to meet and discuss with beneficiaries, members of the Village Council, Community Management Committees (CMC) and beneficiaries. The focus of the discussion was on issues pertaining to the implementation of TASAF interventions including achievements, challenges and lessons learned.
With support from UNDP, the 2016 GPEDC survey was completed and the Tanzania chapter completed as one of the first 10 globally. Results have been compiled and disseminated to DPs for review
As part of the development facilitation exercise, the DP survey was administered, with two notes produced on : a review of the DPG Main effectiveness, and a second on the sector working group performance in addition to regular updates notes sent to the DPG Main members.
The DPG webpage was updated and trainings provided to new focal points
The PFM Coordinator continued assisting the PFM DPG Co chairs on day to day management of the PFMRP program as indicated in the program Operational Manual and taking part in broader PFM issues as well. Further, he continued working closely with the PFMRP Government secretariat both as focal point for DPs and provide support daily operations of the program.

Facilitation of key DPG processes, including statutory meetings and DPG Field Trip Effective support to the co-chairs for the aid architecture review process Finalization of the capacity building for development results and effectiveness project Communication support and continuously updated Webpage Support to PFM, Environment and PMG DP working group

description.narrative: Minutes of meetings of LPAC, stakeholders,TC, SC. Specific RE technologies for pilot districts and demonstration agreed.

comment.narrative: No Pro-doc available. No specific Rural Energy technologies for pilot districts and demonstration sites.

Country mining vision establishment started
Build capacity for the Ministry of Energy to manage projects in energy sector
Provide support in procurement efforts
Renewable energy technology pilots in 9 districts implemented to provide energy to the rural and marginalized communities

The process of establishment of Country Mining Vision was started with the completion of the mining value management survey which provides opportunity for citizens to share expectations from the extractive sector
Training for government officials on management of the energy projects including contracting and negotiations in the natural gas sectors and policy review and development was conducted.
Procurement support to Ministry of Energy and its subsidiary bodies was carried out. The procured vehicles and equipment aim at improving rural electrification efforts.
Community based energy access projects were implemented through the application of small grants modality. The projects are targeting rural and marginalized communities, with an estimate 22,000 people reached.

Capacity in procurement for development at REA and MEM enhanced CMV development roadmap in place & its implementation promoted Methodologies and tools for conflict risk analysis to eliminate human right abuses and conflicts in the mining sector are in place Energy policy reviewed, REA Act reviewed, RE and EE policies developed, Bio-fuel policy developed Mining sector is integrated into national development plan and poverty reduction strategies. Promotion and launch of SE4ALL initiative Support NGOs, CSOs, CBOs to implement community based renewable energy projects to improve livlihoods Promote gender sensitive interventions

Capacity in proposal development, project management, monitoring & evaluation, financing & auditing and procurement at REA and MEM enhanced - UNDP supported the Government of Tanzania procurement of vehicles and IT equipment. Further capacity building and training on how to enhance their procurement activities will be conducted in 2017. In September 2016, as part of improving performance during transformation of rural livelihoods through provision of modern energy services, REA had capacity building programmes for its staff in various disciplines . These programmes were conducted by the approved service providers from different areas based on the needs. The objectives of the training was to equip the staff with skills and knowledge on projects preparation, planning, monitoring and supervision including preparation of the appropriate tools for project management.
CMV development roadmap in place & its implementation promoted - not achieved but is planned for first half on next year, awaiting confirmation of date from MEM.
Methodologies and tools for conflict risk analysis to eliminate human right abuses and conflicts in the mining sector are in place - not achieved however UNDP is finalizing a Tanzanian Extractives Sector Governance Programme (TEGOP). The project aims at strengthening the national capacity for governing and managing the extractive industry (EI) in Tanzania by supporting the Ministry of Energy and Minerals (MEM) in addressing the policy, legal and institutional challenges as well as the identified capacity gaps. The success of the programme is expected to be enhanced by integrating in the Programme CSR mechanisms and the relationship between business and Human Rights and public communication/community engagement.
Mining sector is integrated into national development plan and poverty reduction strategies. Not achieved as it was dependent on the domestication of the Country Mining Vision - now to take place next year.
SE4ALL initiativ

Promotion of gender sensitive interventions Development of Sustainable Energy for All prodoc to support implementation of the Action agenda and Investment Prospectus Development of the Tanzanian Extractive Industries Governance Programme Support improvement of ICT capacity and data management within MEM Promotion of renewable energy technologies through REA, MEM Support contract management and negotiation skills within REA Capacity in procurement for development at TANESCO is enhanced

- Micro-capital grants implemented for gender-sensitive interventions linking energy access and improved livelihoods. - SE4ALL Implementation in Tanzania ProDoc developed, approved at LPAC and through Government approval processes. - Tanzanian Extractives Industries Governance for Sustainable Development (TEGOSUDE) ProDoc developed. LPAC in 2018. - Tanzanian Renewable Energy Management Information Systems (TREIMS) developed. Official launch to take place under SE4ALL programme in 2018. - REA supported in contract management and negotiation training. - TANESCO officials trained at The Chartered Institute of Procurement and Supply CIPS LEVEL 2. - Conducted a contract negotiation training workshop attended by fifty senior Government officials from the Ministry of Energy and Minerals (MEM), the Attorney General Chambers (AGC), the Tanzania Revenue Authority (TRA), the Petroleum Upstream Regulatory Authority (PURA) and Tanzania Petroleum Development Corporation (TPDC).

description.narrative: Functional advisory support unit. Update and access to website, Use of media for outreach, and coordination framework in communication utilized. Staff trained and manual or guiding document on implementation planning and execution of MKUZA II implementation plan Communication department staff trained and Strategic planning document for the department. M&E tools and reports for FVPO. Training Master Plan and Capacity assessment report for SVPO in place

comment.narrative: The following baseline benchmarks were identified. i. Existence of inadequate or weak advisory support. ii. Low utilization capacity of website, lack of coordination mechanisms, inadequate involvement of Media House in communication. iii. weak writing skills, utilization of ICT in communication, shortage of ICT equipments, & inadequate experience in managing communication department. iv. Lack of M&E tools and strategic plan for the FVPO. v. No training Master Plan for SVPO. vi. Government web site not updated. vii. inadequate/weak processes for coordination, resource mobilization and implementation.

- Undertake participatory review of the national development plan (MKUZA II) - start drafting of the successor Strategy of MKUZA II, which builds on the ZHDR as well as the SDG agenda as well as the outcome document of the Financing for Development conference.
Participatory review of the national development plan (MKUZA II) and drafting of the successor strategy undertaken and is in progress in consultation with various stakeholders
Extension of project to support the activities related to the Evidence planning and monitoring of MKUZA II

i) Participatory consultations meetings were undertaken to develop the Zanzibar Development Strategy(MKUZA II Successor) and M& E framework whereby SDGs, poverty, environment and gender were integrated in the formulation of the successor strategy. ii)M & E capacities of the Zanzibar Government were enhanced namely 58 (27 women and 31 men) in Unguja, 40(15 women and 25 men) in Pemba and 5 technical officers from Zanzibar Planning Commission (4 women and 1 man). This has enabled the partners to develop their results-based sectoral plans aligned with the new development strategy. The final updated Draft MKUZA II Successor Strategy (Zanzibar Development Strategy) is expected to be presented to the Cabinet in December 2016 for approval

Catalysing Agriculture Development in Tanzania
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration
1.Number of Staff recruited 2. Number of analytic studies conducted 3. Number key programmatic interventions undertaken

comment.narrative: ADD is non existent
i) Equip the remaining 11 out of 30 warehouses that were rehabilitated ii) Train 90 farmer based organizations (FBOs) and 30 warehouse operators iii) Link warehouses to potential markets

i) The remaining 11 out of 30 warehouses have been equipped with appropriate tools and structures to create a proper storage environment. ii) a total of 76 (14 female; 62 male) farmer based organizations (FBOs) leaders were trained in organizational skills to enable them to manage smallholder farmers economic undertakings. Further, a total of 48 warehouse operators were trained on warehouse management. iii) 41 warehouses were merged with 4 buyers and memorandum of understanding was signed with 7 local government authorities to enable farmers sell their rice and maize to the buyers

1. Engage a Private Service Provider to support COWABAMA and smallholder irrigation schemes in Mbozi and Mbeya districts 2. Rehabilitate 50 warehouse under COWABAMA and in the irrigation schemes 3. Equip TANSIS to conduct soil health survey 4 Support establishment of ASDPII Coordination mechanism

1.Target number 1 was not met. The activity related to it was put on hold pending clarity from the government on host institution for the Agricultural Delivery Division (ADD) following unexpected disbandment of the President Delivery Bureau under which ADD was hosted. 2. Target number 2 was not met. This was due expected change of policy by the funding partner -BMGF, not to fund physical infrastructure and construction related interventions under the project such as the COWABAMA initiative. 3. Necessary equipment were procured for for TANSIS to conduct soil health survey: The soil health survey soil fertility mapping and fertilizer usage exercise has been ongoing in the high agriculture potential regions in Tanzania which are covered by SAGCOT. This will eliminate the current practice of blanket fertilizer application, which is both wasteful, and in some cases detrimental to soil health. It will also enable appropriate blending of fertilisers for different soil types. 4. ADD provided substantive technical support to the validation ASDP II and formulation of its coordination mechanism. The ASDP II is now ready for implementation.

description.narrative:
# of aspirants (women, youth & PWDs) trained
# of trained aspirants seeking nomination as candidates in 2015 general elections
# of the trained aspirants that get nominated as candidates for the 2015 general elections (and those that get elected)
initiatives adopted by political parties to promote inclusive participation within party structures and in political and electoral processes

comment.narrative:
Low levels of participation of women, youth and PWDs in electoral processes (2010 general elections)
Party structures are male dominated and decisions taken favour men e.g. parties tend to nominate male candidates since they are perceived as more likely to get elected compared to women, youth & PWDs
Aspirants lack adequate capacity to effectively engage in electoral processes

Political parties' leaders sensitized on gender equality and social inclusion.
Political parties' leaders and party agents trained on electoral laws and processes.
Training of potential aspirants delivered.

182 political party leaders, 70 women political leaders and 346 regional level party leaders sensitised on gender equality and social inclusion to foster their support for women, youth & PWDs as aspirants and candidates in the general elections. As a result of the training, political parties made commitments to support women, youth & PWDs in furthering their leadership within political party structures and processes. In addition, 10 political parties constitutions and manifestos were reviewed to address gender gaps
A total of 1,282(845 women, 360 youth & 77 PWDs) potential aspirants drawn from the database of aspirants established earlier were trained to enhance their skills to effectively engagement in political and electoral processes. 72 of these trained aspirants got nominated by their political parties as candidates in the 2015 general elections.

Gender Equality and Social Inclusion Policy developed for the ORPP
Strategic Plan developed for the ORPP
Lessons learned on gender equality and social inclusion in political and electoral processes captured

A Gender Equality and Social Inclusion Policy was developed for the ORPP. This provided the ORPP with a strategic and operational framework to effectively address gender equality and social inclusion in the implementation of its mandate.
A Strategic Plan was developed for the ORPP thereby providing the ORPP with a five year road-map to guide its operation and execution of its mandate.
Studies on gender equality and social inclusion with regards to the 2015 general elections were conducted and best practices and lessons learned captured. These will inform future programming on gender equality and social inclusion in political and electoral processes. For example:
(i) a media analysis of local newspapers during the elections was undertaken to examine how messages targeting women, youth and PWDs in elections were framed. The information gathered will inform awareness raising of editors, who are key decision makers in the newsrooms, and journalists, who are responsible for daily media reporting, to improve coverage of women as credible leaders and candidates in future elections.
(ii) An assessment of the training delivered for aspirants was undertaken including their engagement in the party nominations. This helped capture challenges encountered by the aspirants during party nominations and draw lessons from the process. 15 success stories were selected to be showcased in a publication of successful case studies through which important lessons and best practices can be captured. 10 of those have been used for the production of an audio visual documentary. These products will be used for advocacy work aimed at promoting participation of women in leadership

description.narrative:
# of the targeted laws reformed
Evidence of integration of gender equality and social inclusion principles in the revised laws
Establishment of dispute resolution mechanisms to address inter & intra-party disputes

comment.narrative:
Observer reports have reiterated the need for a review of the electoral legal and institutional framework to address existing gaps and facilitate inclusive participation in electoral processes
4 key laws targeted for review: The Constitution Review Act 2012; The National Elections Act 2010; Political Parties Act 1992 & Elections Expenses Act 2010.
Reforms in electoral dispute resolution anticipated through the introduction of minimum reforms or through the Draft Constitution if enacted into law

Support provided in the conduct of the Constitutional Referendum
Revision to the Political Parties Act, Elections Expenses Act and the Political Parties Code of Conduct finalised
Dispute resolution mechanisms established for the ORPP to address inter & intra party disputes
Training of the Judiciary on electoral dispute resolution delivered
At least 80% of the electoral disputes lodged with the judiciary resolved within the stipulated time frame (1 year)

*The Constitutional Referendum earlier scheduled for 30th April 2015 was postponed indefinitely
Draft amendments to the Political Parties Act and the Elections Expenses Act were finalised and await tabling in Parliament. Parliament was dissolved before the Amendments could be tabled for enactment into law.
The Political Parties Code of Conduct was revised and adopted by all 22 registered Political Parties. The revised Code of Conduct integrated principles to promote gender equality and social inclusion in the 2015 elections.
Dispute resolution mechanisms (DRM) were established for the ORPP and staff trained trained on application of the DRM.A key recommendation from the process was to have the DRM institutionalised and integrated in the Amended Political Parties Act. The project will follow up on this in 2016
Approximately 165 Judiciary staff from Mainland and Zanzibar were trained on electoral dispute resolution aimed at enhancing their effective adjudication of electoral related disputed in 2015 elections and beyond. Participants included Judges of the Supreme Court and the High Courts, Magistrates, Registrars and State Attorneys. As a result of the training, the judiciary committed to resolve all electoral related disputes within a period of 6 months
By the end of 2015, a total of 54 petitions for Members of Parliament were lodged with the High Court in relation to the 2015 general elections. 30 of these had been decided upon and 24 were pending. The law does not provide for petitioning of the presidential results. For Councillors, a total of 193 petitions were lodged in various Resident Magistrate Courts in the country. All have been decided upon with a few appeals pending for decision in the High Court.

Dispute resolutions mechanisms integrated in the revised Political Parties Act to ensure that they are anchored in law
Time taken by the judiciary to resolve electoral related disputes reduced in comparison to 2010 elections and in line with the judiciary's commitment following the training delivered by the project to further reduce the timeline from 1 year as stipulated by the law to 6 months.
Judiciary supported in the establishment of a compendium on electoral laws, development of a digest of election cases and a resource tool on election practises and procedures.

The recommendation to integrate the dispute resolution mechanisms in the revised Political Parties Act was adopted by the Political Parties Council paving way for their integration the the Amended Act.
Out of the 54 election petitions lodged, 51 have been resolved and 3 are pending. 1 is pending because the matter was sent to the court of appeal on a preliminary matter and it is yet to be resolved. 2 are currently being heard and are at an advanced stage with the ruling expected by the end of November. The deadline for completion of all petitions is 25th November for the High Court. Out of the decided petitions in the High Court there are 3 appeals in the Court of Appeal pending decision.
A compendium on electoral laws has been established, digest of election cases and a resource tool on election practices and procedures developed. These are useful resources for judicial officers when handling electoral disputes and in their day to day activities. Copies of these resources have been printed and disseminated to judicial officers across the country.

description.narrative:
operational and institutional efficiency of the EMBs in conducting key tasks in the electoral processes
quality of key plans developed by the EMBs; timeliness in implementation
# of eligible voters registered

comment.narrative:
Observer reports highlighted the need for EMBs to have detailed Elections Calendars
EMBs perceived as lacking independence, transparency and professionalism in undertaking their work
In 2010 elections, stakeholders expressed low confidence in the integrity of the voter register stating double registration, missing names, incorrect polling stations as the most prominent causes for inaccuracy. In 2015 elections, a government decision was made to have all voters registered afresh using the Biometric Voter Registration technology

EMBs supported in planning and execution of key tasks
Voter Education targeting women, youth and PWDs delivered with extended reach
EMBs conduct the October elections in a professional and efficient manner

EMBs were supported in the review of regulations and guidelines. The Code of conduct for observers was revised and observer guidelines for 2015 general elections developed. These were availed in English and Kiswahili, printed and distributed to domestic and international observers during the accreditation process. The Code of Conduct for Political Parties was also revised
Approximately 85% of the plans developed by the EMBs were implemented in 2015 elections. Some like the Gender Equality & Social Inclusion Policy and the Strategic Plan require a longer term implementation time frame.
Support was provided to NEC in the establishment of the mainlands Voter Education Reference Group (VERG), drawing on the success of Zanzibars VERG, as a platform for coordination and exchange of information & guidelines on voter education
Technical assistance was provided in content generation for voter education targeting women, youth and PWDs and in dissemination of voter education with extended reach to hard-to-reach areas. The 28 DEP supported communited radios delivered programming on inclusive and peaceful elections and provided extended coverage to approximately 16 million listeners.
NEC registered 22,751,292 eligible voters (96% of the estimated population of voting age and ZEC registered 503,860 eligible voters out of which 45.7% were youth i.e. 24.4% women, 21.3%men youth.
Credible and peaceful general elections held in 2015. The elections were deemed by domestic and international observers as being credible and largely peaceful. The observers commended the EMBs, particularly NEC, in delivering the elections in an efficient and professional manner

EMBs internal reflection exercise supported via BRIDGE Module on Post-elections activities
ICT capacity of NEC staff strenthened
Lessons Learned on 2015 general elections captured

The BRIDGE Module on Post-elections activities benefitted more than 50 NEC staff at different levels of the institution (directors, heads of sections and NEC staff in general). It provided an opportunity for NEC to reflect on their performance in the 2015 general elections, identify challenges and draw lessons to inform future management of elections in Tanzania. In addition, 2 NEC staff were fully accredited as BRIDGE facilitators thereby establishing a critical mass of fully accredited BRIDGE facilitators within the EMB, who can in turn train their colleagues.
A total of 134 (72 women, 62 men) NEC staff benefitted from the DEP-sponsored training in Microsoft Office package while 10 IT staff benefited from a specialized IT training (Cisco Certified Network Associate (CCNA); Microsoft Certified Solutions Expert (MSCE); Microsoft Certified Systems Developer (MSCD); and Oak Ridge Automatic Computer and Logical Engine (ORACLE). These were aimed at enhancing staff capacity to exploit IT in the performance of their roles in the post-elections phase and beyond thereby enhancing NECs performance.
Several post-elections studies on the 2015 elections were conducted that helped capture good practises and draw lessons to inform future programming.These included studies on support to aspirants and party nomination processes, a media gender analysis, a conflict analysis, study on the peace dialogues platforms and a value for money case study. A terminal evaluation of the project was also conducted that helped capture best practises and draw lessons form the 2015 general elections. The evaluation makes specific recommendations that will inform UNDPs programming and future electoral support in Tanzania.

Project management undertaken in a transparent, efficient, effective and sustainable manner

Timeliness and quality of project reports

Project Document developed and await approval

Regular TC and SC meetings held
Quality project reports delivered in a timely manner

Regular meetings with implementing partners held and quarterly planning and review undertaken
Mid-term Evaluation of the Project conducted and findings and recommendations used to inform project implementation
Regular SC & TC meetings held. Among the key decisions taken was the approval of the projects 2015/16 Annual Work Plan and Budget and the extension of the projects duration from June 2016 to December 2016.
The project delivered 4 Quarterly Progress Reports and one Annual Report . In addition, the project produced Weekly Bulletins and Monthly Newsletters to keep stakeholders informed on the latest happenings in the electoral context.

Project Office relocated to the UN House in Masaki
Regular progress reports delivered
Independent Audit of the project conducted
At least 2 Project Board Meeting held
Final Project Evaluation Conducted

The project office was successfully relocated in March from Upanga to the UN House in Masaki
The project delivered an Annual Report and Quarterly Progress Reports
An independent audit of the project was conducted in June and the office is in the process of implementing the audit recommendations
The Union Technical Committee Meeting was held on 30th August while the Steering Committee meeting is scheduled for 7th December.
An independent evaluation of the project was conducted (Oct. - Nov.) that captured good practices and lessons to inform future programming. A Management Response has been prepared.
