description.narrative:
# of police trained in public order command and in Gender & Human Rights
Reduction in reports of excessive use of force and human rights violation by the police in responding to election related events
Establishment of multi-stakeholder peace dialogue forums

comment.narrative:
Police accused of being partisan, excessive use of force & human rights violation in responding to election-related incidents of disruption to public order
Some districts have been identified as hotspots for election/political related conflict
No forum in place for regular engagement & collaboration amongst electoral stakeholders

At least 10,000 Police officers trained in Gender & Human Rights
Police apply an appropriate response (no use of excessive force and no violations of human rights) to incidents of disruption to public order in electoral related events
Police radio communication extended to newly created districts and regions to ensure country wide coverage; Upgrading of IRRS finalised and system operational by October general elections
Active engagement of stakeholders in the multi-stakeholder peace dialogue forums

The project delivered additional radio communication equipment to cover the newly created districts and regions thereby facilitating country-wide coverage of police radio communication systems. The IRRS was upgraded and 40 operators trained in its operation. The system went live in October and was used to track and respond to election related incidents during the elections.
Approximately 480 police officers were trained in public order command and 15,195 police officers (21% women; 79% men) benefited from a cascaded training on Gender, Human Rights and the Role of the Police in Elections aimed at enabling the police uphold human rights in undertaking their work. Preliminary media reports during the elections period and election observer reports indicated that the police were more friendly in the 2015 elections compared to previous elections.
370 (33% women, 67% men) dialogue conveners were trained, out of which 88% were youth.
17 dialogues forums were held at national level and district level dialogues held in 22 districts in the Mainland and in 11 districts in Zanzibar.
There was continued stakeholders engagement in peace dialogue forums with regular dialogues being held at different levels across the country before, during and after the general elections. These were particularly relevant following the nullification of elections in Zanzibar that saw increased tensions particularly in Pemba which is an opposition stronghold. The dialogue forums provided safe spaces to address local level tensions thereby contributing to a peaceful electoral environment.

strengthened collaboration among stakeholders to mitigate risks to peaceful elections
Conflict assessment of the 2015 elections conducted to establish the effectiveness of the peace-building dialogue processes and to inform the development of a strategy on conflict prevention and peace-building.
Strategy on conflict prevention and peace-building developed.

Additional dialogues were supported to address increased tensions following the nullification of elections in Zanzibar and subsequent re-run elections. The peace dialogues helped address local level tensions in a timely manner. The dialogue platforms identified challenges that existed during and after elections and developed resolutions on how to deal with local-level challenges
A Conflict Analysis Study was undertaken that culminated in the updating of the 2014 conflict assessment (conducted by the project to inform the design of the dialogue work).
A review of the dialogue platforms was conducted that revealed that the DEP supported interventions and actors to initiate or strengthen dialogue platforms in different ways and at different levels were highly relevant and all reasonably effective in achieving their objectives. The different initiatives provided opportunities to enhance effectiveness through cross-fertilisation and a Dialogue Practitioners Network was also formed.
A strategy on conflict prevention and peace building has been developed and will be implemented through the upcoming new UNDP project on Citizens' Voice and Participation. The new project will deal with conflict and issues over which there are tensions. It is informed by the updated conflict analysis conducted by DEP.

description.narrative: - % of national coverage by climate monitoring system - frequency of data transmission and reception of current weather and river levels in Tanzania meteorological agency and the water basin authorities, - % of population with access to climate information and improved flood and drought warnings % of which are women, - type of development planning framework informed by climate information in Meru and Liwale districts,

comment.narrative: 50% project of the territory is covered by some form of weather monitoring, but only 30% by automated weather stations. River stations are read manually every 2 hours during rain fall but data is transmitted at various frequencies depending on observer capacity. Tanzania meteorological net work operates at various frequencies with most rapid transmission being hourly from the automated weather stations and slowest being daily manual readings transmitted on weekly basis. ) people in the project sites have access to improved climate information, drought or early warnings, high level frameworks include climate change and mitigating measures but no plans at local level

Procurement and installation of additional 20 automated weather stations for TMA
Initiating process of establishing SOPs for Tanzania Meteorological Agency and Disaster Management Department
Initiating process of establishing 24/7 climate and weather operation centre at Prime Minister's Office
Capacity building for government officials

Procurement of additional 20 weather stations was completed. SOPs have not been established but the process of development and consultation between relevant institutions has started. Consultancy has started to design and operationalize the 24/7 operation center. Capacity building was carried out through South - South and North-South cooperation.

Flood forecasting model using rainfall and river flow data in Pangani and Ruvuma Basin Water developed Standard Operating Procedures for droughts and floods in consultation with all partners at national and local level, including NGOs and the media developed An integrated database of climate/hydro information that can be accessed by sectoral users in real time, housed in TMA established Midterm Review of Strengthening Climate Information and Early Warning Project conducted

Flood forecasting model using rainfall and river flow data in Pangani and Ruvuma Basin Water not yet completed. However the installation of 20 Automated Weather Stations (AWS) has started; TMA completed the survey areas for installing AWS. As of end of Q4 - four stations have been completed, six stations have technicians on-site while the remainder have the system on-site awaiting installation. In Ruvuma and Southern Coast Basin, work is still on-going for 5 new hydro-metric stations in five rivers and ten automatic rainfall gauges in ten villages distributed in four districts. In Pangani River Basin construction is on-going for ten mini-weather stations. Majority of installed weather stations are transmitting data to Pangani server based in Moshi.
Standard Operating Procedures for droughts and floods in consultation with all partners at national and local level, including NGOs and the media was developed for Arumeru and Liwale. Stakeholder workshop on the SOP was held 16th December for review and the final Standard Operating Procedures for droughts and floods was presented to PMO on 28th December.
An integrated database of climate/hydro information that can be accessed by sectoral users in real time, housed in TMA still under development. However, in August, data training was conducted with the purpose of enhancing the capacity of Numerical Weather Prediction experts at Central Forecasting Office to adopt data assimilation technique in Weather Research and Forecasting model (WRF) using available computing facilities at Julius Nyerere International Airport for improving the accuracy of the model forecasts. This data assimilation technique will further use local observation station networks which include SYNOP data from TMA manual stations, radio sound data and the AWS of the CIEWS project. The technical training was aimed at enhancing the capacity of the TMA to reduce the impacts of extreme weather in context of Disaster Risk Reduction through provision

Flood forecasting model using rainfall and river flow data in Pangani and Ruvuma Basin Water developed Rescue, digitize and achieve relevant available historical data from all ministeries relevant to the 2 pilot districts to be integrated in the global database Standard Operating Procedures for droughts and floods in consultation with all partners at national and local level, including NGOs and the media developed and Emergency Preparedness and Response Plans (EPRPs) of Liwale and Arumeru districts in place. Support TMA in the Inspection and configuration of the 36 new AWSs Crowd sourced hazard feedback platform is installed Climate Change and Climate Hazards included in local development plans and land use plans in Liwale and Meru districts.

The project has made some progress on the installation of flood forecast management system. Working together with UNDP Multi-Country Support Programme to Strengthen Climate Information and Resilient Development in Africa (CIRDA), Ministry of Water and Irrigation and the Tanzania Meteorological Agency, the BRLi Company Limited, a France consultancy firm, has been hired to install the hydrological solutions for integrated Water Resources Management System (IWRMS) in Ruvuma and Pangani basins. The assignment commenced in June 2017. The BRLi team met with stakeholders to identify the needs, checking the stations, data quality controls, transmissions, existing systems and data storage to provide the foundation for installing the IWRMS system in Tanzania. The process of designing the system is still progressing.The system will ready for use in June 2018. Pangani River Basin and Ruvuma and southern Coast basin has selected to the two pilot basins where the IWRMS will demonstrated and in future be upscaled to whole country. This will enhance the early warning system in Tanzania and support the identification of the most vulnerable areas for drought and floods. This is among of the key products the project needs to generate to support decisions and development of long term development plans for the pilot districts
The project has supported the data rescuing, digitization and archiving of historical data relevant for Arumeru and Liwale districts. The data has been shifted from papers to electronic format. The project has assisted the TMA to procure equipment for data digitization (Computers and software, furniture and printer to support the digitisation process. The selected climatological data from TMA relevant Arumeru and Liwale were digitised. The process of migrating the data to national database is still progressing.The project has finalised the establishment of a national integrated database for climate and hydrology information. The Ruvuma and Southern Coast Basins Water Boards have received 5 hydrological stations 40 river gauges and 10 rain gauges The equipment has been installed
The project continued building capacity on the application of new technologies
8 instrumentation specialists from TMA and the Ministry of Water have been trained on the operation of the newly supplied AWS
14 hydrologists from the Pangani and Ruvuma Basins have received onsite practical training on the installation of the hydrological equipment
20 government staff from implementing partners have participated in different international workshops funded by the CIRDA programme from February 2014 to 30 June 2015 These workshops built capacity on the application of various technologies which aim to improve the collection and processing of data and the identification of opportunities for engagement with the private sector to generate revenue and render sustainable the weather services All these efforts contributed to the improvement of weather services and have informed the process of cost recovery in the country
273 community representatives from Liwale and Arumeru districts have been trained on the application of climate information products to mitigate cope with droughts and floods

description.narrative: Efficient and effective use of hydrometeorological and environmental information for making early warnings and longterm development plans

comment.narrative:
30 of people in the project sites have access to some climate information but no people in the project sites have access to improved climate information drought or early warnings
TAFSIP MKUKUTA II and other high level frameworks include climate change and mitigating measures but no plans at local level

At least 70 of residents in the targeted areas benefit from improved climate information drought or early warnings
Local land use plans and development plans in Meru and Liwale include climate change risk information

Indicator 1
Finalized feasibility study on the setup of a 24hour emergency operation centre EOC within the Prime Ministers Office Disaster Management Department PMODMD The study includes background information on the management of the EOC its functions and structure and personnel requirements the required technical expertise and equipment communication equipment criteria for site selection possibilities to engage with the private sector for longterm sustainability list of agenciesstakeholders including their roles and estimated budget The EoC will be a central command and control facility responsible for carrying out the principles of emergency preparedness and management in the country
Mobilizing local disastermanagement committees and CBOs to participate in the simulation exercise and crowdsourcing through consultations and training
Facilitating field visits and stakeholder consultations to understand how users of early warning advisories use the information for managing climate and weatherrelated risks and how their decision frameworks affect the interpretations of advisories and warnings
The project commissioned a study to assess the efficiency of the available explicit and implicit operating procedures for issuing early warnings The study provided background information on the status of the Tanzania Emergency and Preparedness Plan and a basis for the development of Standard Operating Procedures SOPs for droughts and floods The SOPs will highlight each partners roles and responsibilities the types of early warning messages the appropriate responses the resources and communication pathways to reach local communities The project has initiated the process of developing the SOPs The 1st draft for the Liwale district is done and it focuses on the processes to be undertaken by all stakeholders in their efforts to mitigatecope with floods and droughts
Indicators 1 and 2
Trained 273 and 157 community representatives from the Liwale and Arumeru district respectively The 273 community representatives were trained as trainers for trainers The trainers were given the responsibility to disseminate their knowledge and skills to their fellow village members The training sessions focused on the use of climate information to overcome droughts and floods and on the downscaling of climate information at the local level More than 70 of the community members of the targeted villages will be exposed to the improved knowledge Ultimately its application to the development of village plans will contribute to the development of district development plans The training was extended to 30 district sector heads of the Liwale district and 28 sector heads of the Arumeru district

description.narrative: (i) Robust M&E and Management Information System for the Productive Social Safety Nets (PSSN) (ii) NSPF and PSSN indicators incorporated into NBS national, thematic and panel survey instruments (iii) National Social Protection Framework (NSPF) in place (iv) National Social Protection Framework M&E and Implementation Plan developed

comment.narrative: (i) Weak M&E and Management Information System for the Productive Social Safety Nets (PSSN) (ii) Limited inclusion of social protection indicators in National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) national, thematic and panel survey instruments (iii) No National Social Protection Framework (NSPF) in place (iv) National Social Protection Framework M&E and Implementation Plan developed

- Review of National Social Protection Framework completed - Data capture centres in the selected 22 Project Authority Areas established and functioning - Productive Social Safety Nets (PSSN) Management Information System (MIS) decentralised to the selected 22 LGAs - At least 30 TASAF M&E staff trained on data capture and monitoring - At least 30 front line workers trained on M&E and data capture

- Review of National Social Protection Framework has been completed; awaiting for endorsement by the Cabinet Secretariat - Data capture centres in the selected 22 Project Authority Areas have been established and are now functioning - Productive Social Safety Nets (PSSN) Management Information System (MIS) decentralisation completed - 30 TASAF M&E staff completed training on data capture and monitoring - 30 front line workers completed training on M&E and data capture

- Social protection indicators included in National Pannel Survey - Development process of NSPF implementation plan and M&E framework initiated - Poverty Monitoring Master Plan (PMMP) with social protection indicators developed

- Draft National Panel Survey with social protection indicators developed and stakeholder consultations planned for early 2017. - Development of NSPF implementation plan and M&E framework initiated, which will be completed by February 2017. - Development of Poverty Monitoring Master Plan (PMMP) initiated with key social protection indicators identified

- TASAF staff trained on data analysis packages, evaluation of social protection programmes, and gender sensitive and results-based monitoring and reporting - Poverty Monitoring Master Plan (PMMP) with social protection indicators finalized and approved - Institutional assessment of challenges, gaps, and opportunities of implementing, coordinating, and monitoring social protection interventions in Tanzania conducted

- TASAF staff completed training on data analysis packages, evaluation of social protection programmes, and gender sensitive and results-based monitoring and reporting - Draft Poverty Monitoring Master Plan (PMMP) with social protection indicators developed and under final review process - Institutional assessment of challenges, gaps, and opportunities of implementing, coordinating, and monitoring social protection interventions in Tanzania conducted
